document.masterDocTitle: A new species of crane fly, Pedicia (Pedicia) goldsworthyi (Diptera: Pediciidae), from eastern North America

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of crane fly, Pedicia (Pedicia) goldsworthyi (Diptera: Pediciidae), from eastern North America

heading.emphasis:
Pedicia ( Pedicia ) goldsworthyi Petersen
, new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Medium­large
Pedicia
(
Pedicia
) species. Wing veins CuA, Sc, and M, and distal chord of wing widely suffused with black. Vein CuA 1 suffused with black until wing margin. Prescutum with 4 brown stripes, medial 2 narrowly divided. Ninth tergite with 2 medial rows and 2 anterior tufts of elongate golden setae. Gonocoxite short, with an elongate mesoventral lobe that exceeds length of gonocoxite. Mesoventral lobe with a mesodorsal enlargement equipped with numerous stout black setae.

Pedicia ( Pedicia ) goldsworthyi
has a wide eastern North American distribution extending from Liberty, Maine, south to North Carolina, and west to Lake Itasca, Minnesota, and Aweme, Manitoba. The prevalence of collection records from Pennsylvania may reflect the increased sampling that this area has received, rather than species abundance.

Pedicia ( Pedicia ) goldsworthyi
was well represented in museum collections, in all cases identified as P. a l b i v i t t a , based on the coloration of wing vein CuA 1 to the wing margin. This confusion likely resulted from the use of an existing taxonomic key (
Alexander 1942
) that was limited to wing coloration characters. Additional records and museum­held specimens of
P. goldsworthyi
are likely to exist in collections similarly misidentified as P. a l b i v i t t a . The five eastern North American species, while being very similar in morphology and coloration, may be separated by means of the included key.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Light micrographs of
Pedicia ( Pedicia ) goldsworthyi
n. sp.
1. Male hypopygium, dorsal view. 2. Interio­lateral view of gonocoxite. 3. Lateral view of male hypopygium. 4. Wing with arrow indicating vein CuA1. Scale bar = 1 mm. (abbreviations: 9s: ninth abdominal segment, gxt: gonocoxite, mvl: mesoventral lobe of gonocoxite).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Collection dates show that adults of
P. goldsworthyi
are active between May and October, with most records in July and August. Increased examination of collected specimens of
P. albivitta
should yield additional new records and will help to refine the distribution of
P. goldsworthyi
. The larval stage of
P. goldsworthyi
is currently undescribed, though it is likely to be similar to that of
P. albivitta
, the larvae of which are predaceous and known from springs, seeps, and lake and stream margins, where they live in saturated soils (
Alexander 1920
).
